chapters.chapterTitle: The Ascension and Waiting for the Spirit

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 1:1-12 aloud, paying attention to the phrase 'until He was taken up' in verses 3-4 and the disciples' reaction in verses 8-10.
tips: Notice the phrase 'until He was taken up' appears three times (v.3, v.4, v.10) in the narrative of Jesus' appearances
Pay attention to the emotional shift from hope to uncertainty as they wait for the Spirit (v.8-10)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO Jesus presented Himself to, WHAT He did for forty days, WHERE it took place, and WHY He commanded the disciples to wait for the Spirit.
tips: Include the forty days of appearances (v.3-4)
Note the disciples' question about the kingdom restoration (v.6)
Describe the command to wait in Jerusalem for the Spirit (v.4-5)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Jesus' command to wait (v.4), the cloud lifting (v.9-10), or the disciples' response to the ascension (v.8-10)?
tips: The cloud lifting and Jesus being taken up (v.9-10) shows the divine glory and transcendence of Christ
The disciples' immediate return to Jerusalem and prayer (v.14) demonstrates their response to the ascension
The promise of the Spirit's power to be witnesses (v.8) is a key hope for the disciples

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church about the ascension and the waiting for the Spirit?
tips: Luke emphasizes that the ascension is not the end but the beginning of the church's mission (v.8)
He shows that the disciples' mission is empowered by the Holy Spirit, not by their own strength
This passage connects Christ's ascension to the church's global witness (v.8)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The 40-day period, the disciples' question about the kingdom, or the nature of the Spirit's coming?
tips: The 40 days: In Jewish tradition, 40 days is a time of testing (e.g., Moses on Mount Sinai) but here it's a time of preparation for the disciples
The disciples' question about the kingdom: They are thinking in terms of political restoration of Israel (v.6) which Jesus rejects
The 'baptism of the Holy Spirit' (v.5) is distinct from the Holy Spirit's presence in the church (which comes later)

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of 'waiting for the Spirit' to your life this week?
tips: Set aside time this week to pray and wait for the Holy Spirit's guidance in a specific area (e.g., decision-making)
Identify one area where you need the Spirit's power to be a witness (v.8) and ask for it
Reflect on what it means to 'wait' without being distracted by worldly concerns (v.14)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the ascension and the promise of the Spirit. Ask for the courage to wait and be witnesses.
tips: Thank God that He ascended to reign at the Father's right hand (v.11)
Pray for the Holy Spirit to empower you to be a witness to the ends of the earth (v.8)
Ask God to help you trust in the Spirit's timing rather than your own understanding

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 2:1-41 aloud, paying attention to the description of the sound of a rushing wind (v.2), the tongues of fire (v.3), and the disciples speaking in other tongues (v.4-11).
tips: Notice the phrase 'they were all together' (v.1) sets the scene for unity
Pay attention to the wind as a symbol of God's power (v.2)
Notice the repetition of 'in other tongues' (v.4, 8) showing universal communication

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters (the purpose of the Spirit's outpouring).
tips: Include the 120 disciples in Jerusalem (v.1)
Note the sound of a rushing wind and tongues of fire (v.2-3)
Describe the disciples speaking in other tongues (v.4-11) and the response of the crowd (v.14-41)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the signs of the Spirit (v.2-3), the speaking in tongues (v.4-11), or Peter's declaration of Jesus as Lord (v.36).
tips: The wind and tongues of fire (v.2-3) are immediate and visible signs of God's power
The disciples speaking in other tongues (v.4-11) shows God's universal message
Peter's declaration that Jesus is the Lord and Christ (v.36) is the core of the gospel

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church about the beginning of the church through this passage?
tips: Luke shows that the church begins with the Spirit's outpouring on the disciples (v.1-41)
The church is formed through the gospel message (repentance and baptism) as Peter proclaims (v.38)
The church's identity is rooted in Christ's exaltation and the Spirit's work (v.33-34)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The meaning of speaking in tongues, the role of the Holy Spirit in the church, or Peter's sermon on Jesus?
tips: Speaking in tongues was a sign for conversion of non-Hebrew speakers at that time, not a language for everyday church use
The Spirit's outpouring on all flesh (v.17) is a fulfillment of Joel's prophecy and the beginning of the church age
Peter's focus on Jesus as the crucified and risen one (v.31) shows the church is built on Christ's work

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you respond to the gospel call in Acts 2:38 by repenting and being baptized?
tips: Identify one sin you need to repent of and confess to God
Consider how you can be baptized (in water, symbolically) as a step of obedience
Commit to fellowship with other believers and prayer as the church does (Acts 2:42)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the Spirit's power and ask for the courage to share the gospel.
tips: Thank God for the Spirit's work in bringing people to Christ
Ask for the courage to share the gospel with others
Pray for the church to be united in fellowship and prayer

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 5:1-21 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Peter and Ananias in verses 3-4 and the emotional tone of the church's reaction
tips: Notice the phrase 'Satan filled your heart' (v.3) - it shows the spiritual deception
Pay attention to the repeated phrase 'you have not lied to man but to God' (v.3-4)
Listen for the emotional weight in the phrase 'great fear' (v.11-12)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Ananias and Sapphira) did WHAT (sold property but lied about the proceeds), WHERE (in the early church community), and WHY it matters (the consequence of deception with God)
tips: Include the immediate death of Ananias (v.10)
Note that Sapphira also died after repeating the lie (v.12)
Describe the church's response: great fear and continued ministry (v.11-16)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the lie (v.3-4), Peter's accusation (v.3-4), Ananias' death (v.10), Sapphira's death (v.12), or Peter's declaration (v.29-31)?
tips: Peter's direct challenge: 'Why has Satan filled your heart to lie to the Holy Spirit?' (v.3) - shows the depth of the deception
The immediate consequence: Ananias falls dead (v.10) - emphasizes the gravity of the sin
The church's reaction: 'great fear' (v.11) - highlights the community's response to divine judgment

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church about the danger of deception and the importance of truthfulness in the early church?
tips: The early church was vulnerable to deception because they were new and the Holy Spirit was active
The consequences of lying to God are severe (death) but also the church's response (fear and continued ministry) shows the community's commitment
This event underscores the apostles' authority to speak truth and the divine protection of the church

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The nature of the lie, the death of Ananias and Sapphira, the role of the Holy Spirit in deception, the apostles' imprisonment and release
tips: The phrase 'Satan filled your heart' (v.3) is a strong statement about spiritual deception, but it shows the gravity of the sin
In the early church, the concept of 'lying to the Holy Spirit' might be unfamiliar because the Holy Spirit was not yet the central figure as in later Christianity
The immediate death of both Ananias and Sapphir is a unique event that shows the seriousness of the sin

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply this passage to be honest with God and others this week?
tips: When you have something you want to keep secret (e.g., finances, relationships), ask: 'Is this a lie to God?'
Share your financial transparency with your church community (e.g., if you have a small amount of money you need to give)
Practice the courage of honesty in small ways, like telling a friend the truth about a situation

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the danger of deception and the importance of truthfulness in your life
tips: Thank God for His truth and for the Holy Spirit's guidance in honesty
Ask for courage to be honest when it's difficult (e.g., in financial matters or relationships)
Pray for the church to be a community of integrity and trust

chapters.chapterTitle: The Seven Chosen and Stephen Accused

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 6:1-20 aloud, paying attention to the contrast between the initial complaint about widows and the dramatic trial of Stephen.
tips: Notice the phrase 'full of the Spirit and wisdom' in verse 3
Pay attention to the emotional shift from the Hellenists' complaint to the council's reaction to Stephen's face
The repeated phrase 'witness' (as in false witnesses) in verses 12-13

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it happens (the reason).
tips: Include the Hellenists' complaint about widows being neglected
Note that the apostles choose seven men (including Stephen) to handle distribution
Describe Stephen's trial before the council and the false accusations

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Stephen's selection (v. 3), his face 'like the face of an angel' (v. 15), or the false witnesses (v. 12).
tips: Stephen's face reflecting Christ's glory makes him a powerful witness
The false accusations show the danger of prejudice and the need for truth
The council's reaction (seeing his face like an angel) is a sign of divine favor

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage?
tips: The church must organize for ministry to serve the community
Stephen's anointing by the Spirit shows the church's growing maturity
The trial of Stephen foreshadows his martyrdom and the spread of the gospel

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the Hellenists, the term 'false witnesses', and Stephen's face 'like an angel'?
tips: Hellenists were Jewish converts who spoke Greek, not the entire church
False witnesses are those who lie to get a desired outcome, not necessarily from a bad heart
The angelic face is a sign of Christ's glory, as seen in the New Testament

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: This week, identify one area where the church (or your community) needs to be organized to serve.
tips: Consider how you can step up in a ministry role that others need
Pray for the Holy Spirit to guide the church in serving the community

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the church's ability to organize and serve, and ask for courage to stand for truth when faced with opposition.
tips: Thank God for the church's ability to organize and serve
Pray for courage to stand for truth when faced with opposition
Ask for the Holy Spirit to empower you to be a witness like Stephen

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 7:1-60 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Stephen's speech and the sudden shift in the crowd's reaction.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'you' in Stephen's speech (v. 50)
Pay attention to the phrase 'You stiff-necked people' (v. 50) which is a key emotional turn
Notice the phrase 'Lord Jesus, receive my spirit' (v. 54) as a moment of surrender

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Stephen) does WHAT (recounts Israel's history and charges the Jewish leadership), WHERE (before the Sanhedrin), and WHY (to expose the unfaithfulness of Israel and the coming of Jesus).
tips: Include the key events: Stephen's recount of Abraham, Joseph, and Moses (v. 1-50)
Note the specific charge: 'You stiff-necked people, you always resist the Holy Spirit' (v. 50)
Mention the immediate consequence: the crowd's rage and Stephen's martyrdom (v. 54-60)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Stephen's historical recollection (v. 1-50), the accusation of resisting the Holy Spirit (v. 50), or the moment of death (v. 54-56)?
tips: Stephen's ability to recount the entire history of Israel without interruption (v. 1-50) shows his deep knowledge and purposeful preparation
The phrase 'You stiff-necked people' (v. 50) is a powerful indictment that connects the present to the past (the same as the Israelites in the wilderness)
Stephen's death cry: 'Lord Jesus, receive my spirit' (v. 54) is a model of sacrificial faith and the ultimate surrender to Jesus

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage?
tips: Luke's purpose: To show the continuity of God's plan through the Old Testament and the coming of Jesus (the Righteous One) who is rejected by Israel but exalted by God
The passage demonstrates that the rejection of the Messiah by Israel is part of God's redemptive plan and that Stephen's death is a sign of the coming of the Church
The key theological point: Jesus is the fulfillment of the promises and is seated at God's right hand (v. 55-56)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The historical recollection, the meaning of 'stiff-necked', or the phrase 'the Most High does not dwell in houses made by hands'?
tips: 'Stiff-necked' (v. 50) is a Hebrew term that means stubbornness in rebellion, a recurring theme in the Old Testament
The phrase 'the Most High does not dwell in houses made by hands' (v. 50) refers to the fact that God is spirit and not confined to physical temples
The concept of 'resisting the Holy Spirit' (v. 50) refers to the rejection of the prophetic message and the failure to accept the coming of the Messiah

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to the theme of Jesus being the Righteous One rejected by Israel and the call to forgive enemies as Stephen did. What specific action can you take this week to embody forgiveness and faith in Jesus?
tips: Consider an area where you have been resistant to God's Spirit (like in your relationships)
Practice forgiving someone who has wronged you, just as Stephen forgave his enemies (v. 54-56)
How can you be like Stephen by trusting God's plan even when it seems difficult (like the historical recollection)?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of God's right hand (v. 55-56) and the call to forgive.
tips: Thank God for Jesus who is seated at His right hand and has conquered death
Ask for the courage to forgive those who have wronged you, just as Stephen did
Pray for the church to be a community that remembers the rejection of Jesus and the need for repentance

chapters.chapterTitle: Philip in Samaria and the Ethiopian Eunuch

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 8:1-39 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between Philip and the Ethiopian eunuch in verses 26-39.
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'the Spirit' (v. 38-39) showing divine guidance
Pay attention to the eunuch's immediate response to Philip's explanation of Isaiah 53 (v. 31)
The phrase 'baptized' (v. 38) appears twice in the narrative, emphasizing the importance of the act

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include Philip's healing works in Samaria (v. 6-13)
Note Simon the magician's attempt to buy the power of the Spirit (v. 18-20)
Describe the eunuch's response to Philip's explanation of Isaiah 53 (v. 26-35)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Philip's healing in Samaria (v. 6-13), Simon the magician's story (v. 18-20), or the eunuch's baptism (v. 26-39)?
tips: The eunuch's immediate understanding of Isaiah 53 (v. 31) shows how the gospel breaks cultural barriers
Philip's explanation of Christ as the suffering servant (v. 34) connects the Old Testament to the New
The Spirit's guidance to Philip (v. 38-39) shows the Holy Spirit's active role in spreading the gospel

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage?
tips: Luke emphasizes the universal scope of the gospel (Jews and Gentiles) through Philip's work
The passage shows that the Holy Spirit's power (v. 38-39) is the driving force behind the spread of the gospel
This event fulfills Christ's commission to go and make disciples of all nations (v. 35-39)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts in this chapter.
tips: Simon the magician was a person who claimed to have the power to give the Holy Spirit (v. 18), but Peter rebukes him for trying to buy the gift of the Spirit (v. 20)
An eunuch is a man who has been castrated; in the context of the Roman Empire, the Ethiopian eunuch was a court official (v. 26) and not part of the Jewish community
Isaiah 53 is a prophecy about the suffering servant who bears the sins of many (v. 31), which is fulfilled in Christ

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Tie to a specific theme or action from this passage. What can you do this week?
tips: Pray for the Holy Spirit to guide you in sharing the gospel with someone who is not part of your immediate circle
Reflect on how the gospel is for all people (like the Ethiopian eunuch) and share a word of encouragement with someone who might feel excluded
Consider if you have a place in your life where you are holding back from sharing the gospel (like the eunuch's background)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about this chapter's theme/lesson.
tips: Pray for courage to share the gospel with people who are different from us
Ask God to help us see the 'suffering servant' (Christ) in others and in our own lives
Thank God for the Holy Spirit's guidance that leads us to share the gospel

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 10:1-48 aloud, focusing on Peter's vision (vv. 9-16) and the impact on the Gentiles (vv. 44-48).
tips: Note the three times Peter hears the voice: 'Rise, Peter; kill and eat' (vv. 13-14)
Pay attention to the phrase 'What God has made clean, do not call common' (v. 15)
Observe the emotional shift from Peter's hesitation to his bold declaration in vv. 34-35

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE and WHEN, and WHY it matters in this passage.
tips: Cornelius, a devout centurion, receives a vision from an angel to send for Peter
Peter has a vision of a sheet with animals and hears the voice three times
The Spirit falls on the Gentiles who hear Peter's message

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Peter's vision (vv. 9-16), his declaration of God's universal acceptance (vv. 34-35), or the Spirit falling on Gentiles (vv. 44-48)?
tips: The vision of the sheet and the voice's repeated command challenges Peter's Jewish understanding of clean and unclean
Peter's declaration: 'God shows no partiality' (v. 34-35) is a powerful statement of inclusivity
The immediate response of the Holy Spirit falling on the Gentiles (v. 44) shows God's active work beyond Jewish boundaries

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus and the early church through this passage about Peter and Cornelius?
tips: Luke emphasizes that God's plan of salvation is for all nations, not just Jews
The inclusion of Gentiles in the church demonstrates Christ's universal lordship
This event confirms that the gospel is accessible to all who believe in Jesus

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts in this chapter.
tips: The vision of unclean animals: In Jewish tradition, eating unclean animals was forbidden by law (Leviticus 11), so Peter's initial refusal was rooted in his training
The phrase 'What God has made clean' (v. 15) challenges the idea of clean/unclean in the context of the church
The Spirit falling on Gentiles: This was unprecedented in Jewish tradition and required Peter to overcome his ethnic and religious barriers

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of God showing no partiality to your life this week?
tips: Identify one person from a different cultural or ethnic background and pray for the opportunity to serve them
Reflect on a time when you judged someone based on their background and ask God to change your heart
Practice seeing others as equally valuable in God's eyes by actively seeking to understand their perspective

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about God's universal love and the inclusion of Gentiles in the church.
tips: Thank God for breaking down ethnic and cultural barriers through Jesus
Ask for the courage to be a bridge for people from different backgrounds
Pray for the Holy Spirit to work in the lives of non-Jewish believers and help them become part of the church

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 12:1-26 aloud, paying attention to the tension between Herod's violence and the angel's deliverance.
tips: Notice the phrase 'the church' appears in verses 1 and 2
Pay attention to the emotional shift from fear (v.1) to hope (v.17)
Highlight the phrase 'chained' and 'chains fall off' (v.17)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it occurs, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include the key event: James killed by Herod (v.1-2)
Note Peter's imprisonment and the church's earnest prayer (v.7-8)
Describe the angelic rescue and Herod's death (v.17-26)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Peter's escape (v.17-18), Rhoda's reaction (v.17), or Herod's death (v.23)?
tips: Peter's immediate escape without a struggle shows God's power
Rhoda's joyful realization that it's Peter's angel (v.17) is a powerful moment of community
Herod's death by an angel (v.23) is a dramatic warning about self-exaltation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage?
tips: Luke emphasizes that God's deliverance comes through the church's prayer and the power of Christ
This passage shows the contrast between human pride (Herod) and divine humility (Christ)
The growth of the word of God (v.24) is the ultimate outcome

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The role of the angel, Herod's death, or the church's prayer?
tips: The term 'struck down by an angel' (v.23) refers to a divine judgment, not a physical death by a human
Herod's actions against the church (v.1-2) were motivated by his anger over the church's influence, not religious reasons
The church's prayer (v.8) was an example of intercessory prayer, which is a key theme in the early church

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the church's earnest prayer to your life this week?
tips: Choose one area where you need God's intervention and pray for it
Like the church in Acts 12, pray for someone who is in trouble
Commit to praying for at least one person each day

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for His deliverance and ask for humility.
tips: Thank God for the power of Christ to rescue us from our enemies
Pray for the church to continue praying earnestly for one another
Ask God to humble Herod's pride in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 15:1-29 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue between the men from Judea and Paul/Barnabas in verses 1-3, and Peter's testimony in verses 7-9.
tips: Notice the phrase 'circumcision according to the custom of Moses' (v1-2)
Pay attention to Peter's question: 'Why do you put a yoke on their necks that neither our fathers nor we could bear?' (v9)
Listen for the repetition of 'saved by grace' in Peter's testimony (v9)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT they are debating, WHERE the council meets, and WHY they are sending the letter.
tips: Include the men from Judea who teach that circumcision is required for salvation
Note that the council is held in Jerusalem
Describe the resolution: the decree for Gentiles to abstain from four specific things (idols, sexual immorality, strangled, blood)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider Peter's testimony (v7-9), James' decree (v18-29), or the letter sent by the church (v29).
tips: Peter's phrase 'Why do you put a yoke on their necks that neither our fathers nor we could bear?' shows the burden of the law being placed on Gentiles without a basis in the covenant
The decree in v18-29 is specific and practical: four things to avoid (idols, sexual immorality, strangled, blood)
The letter sent by the church (v29) is a model of unity and clear instruction

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage about the Jerusalem Council?
tips: Luke emphasizes that salvation is by grace through Christ, not by the law (circumcision)
The Spirit is given equally to Jews and Gentiles who believe
The decree shows that the church can be unified without requiring Gentiles to follow Jewish law

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The requirement for circumcision? Why the council was necessary? The four specific prohibitions?
tips: Circumcision as a requirement for salvation: in the context of the early church, this was a major point of contention
The term 'yoke' (v9) refers to the burden of the law, which the apostles were not willing to place on Gentiles
The four prohibitions (v28-29) are not the entire law but specific cultural and moral boundaries

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the Jerusalem decree to your life this week? Specifically, what area of your life requires you to avoid the four prohibitions?
tips: Consider if you are avoiding idols (in thought, behavior, or objects)
Think about sexual immorality and how it affects your relationships
Reflect on the issue of blood (which could be metaphorical for violence or sin)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the unity in Christ and the grace of salvation. Ask for courage to follow Christ without being burdened by unnecessary rules.
tips: Thank God for the Spirit being given to Gentiles
Pray for the church to be united in Christ without ethnic or legal barriers
Ask God to help you avoid the four prohibitions in your life

questions.instruction: Read Acts 17:1-34 aloud, paying attention to the dialogue in the synagogues and the speech at the Areopagus.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'the Christ' (v.3) and 'this Jesus I proclaim' (v.3)
Pay attention to the emotional shift from hope in Thessalonica to the city's reaction in Athens
The phrase 'turned the world upside down' (v.6) appears in the context of the mob's reaction

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, summarize WHO, WHAT, WHERE, WHEN, and WHY Paul and Silas travel to these cities.
tips: Include the three cities: Thessalonica, Berea, and Athens
Note the Bereans' response: examining the Scriptures daily (v.11) and the mob's reaction in Thessalonica (v.5-6)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's message in Thessalonica (v.3), the Bereans' diligence (v.11), or Paul's speech at the Areopagus (v.22-31).
tips: The Bereans' commitment to examine the Scriptures daily (v.11) shows a deep engagement with truth
Paul's declaration of the unknown God (v.24) and the call to repent (v.30-31) is profound and universal
The phrase 'this Jesus I proclaim to you is the Christ' (v.3) is a clear declaration of identity

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus and the church about the spread of the gospel through Paul's journeys?
tips: Luke emphasizes that the gospel is being preached in diverse cities and that the response varies (e.g., Bereans vs. Thessalonica mobs)
The resurrection of Christ is the central event that validates the gospel and the only way to salvation
The call to repent is universal (v.30-31)

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The cultural context of Athens, the meaning of 'turned the world upside down', and the concept of 'appointed a day of judgment' in this chapter.
tips: 'Turned the world upside down' (v.6) refers to the radical impact of the gospel on society, not a literal inversion
The Areopagus was the city council of Athens where philosophers debated (v.22-23)
'Appointed a day of judgment' (v.31) refers to Christ's second coming, not a specific day in the past

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you practice the Bereans' example of examining the Scriptures daily in your life this week?
tips: Choose one Bible verse to study in depth (e.g., Acts 17:11) and ask: 'Does this align with my life?'
Write down one truth from the Scripture that you can apply to a current situation
Share your findings with one person this week

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the resurrection of Christ and the call to repent.
tips: Thank God for the resurrection of Christ as the basis of salvation
Ask for the courage to share the gospel in your community
Pray for the Bereans' example of examining Scripture in your life

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 21:1-24 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tension between Paul's resolve and the believers' concern.
tips: Notice Paul's repeated phrase 'the will of the Lord be done' (v.24)
Listen for the contrast in tone: the disciples' urgency (v.1-3) vs. Paul's calm resolve (v.22-23)
Pay attention to Agabus' prophecy (v.11) and Paul's response (v.23)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT happens, WHERE it takes place, and WHY it matters.
tips: Include the disciples' warning from Miletus (v.1-3)
Note the purification process advised by James and elders (v.23-24)
Describe the crowd's reaction and Paul's arrest (v.28-24)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: Which part stood out most? Consider: Paul's declaration about dying for Jesus (v.23), the prophecy of Agabus (v.11), or the phrase 'the will of the Lord be done' (v.24)?
tips: Paul's statement 'I am ready not only to be imprisoned but even to die in Jerusalem for the name of the Lord Jesus' (v.23) shows radical commitment
The prophecy of Agabus: 'the Jews at Jerusalem will bind the man whose belt this is and deliver him to the Gentiles' (v.11) foreshadows the trial
The phrase 'the will of the Lord be done' (v.24) captures Paul's submission to God's plan

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church about the cost of following Jesus in Jerusalem?
tips: Luke emphasizes that Paul's obedience to the Lord's will (v.24) leads to the fulfillment of God's purpose
The passage shows that even when the church is concerned, the apostle's faith in Christ's mission remains steadfast
Luke connects Paul's journey to Jerusalem with the broader theme of Christ's crucifixion and the church's unity

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The reason for the purification, the role of the Roman tribune, or the phrase 'the will of the Lord be done'?
tips: The purification requirement (v.23-24) was a cultural practice to show adherence to Jewish law, but it was a test of Paul's identity as a Gentile
'The will of the Lord be done' (v.24) might seem passive, but it reflects Paul's active submission to God's plan
The Roman tribune's role (v.28) is a reminder that Roman authorities had the power to arrest but could not kill without proper procedure

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Paul was ready to die for Jesus. What area of your life requires you to trust God's will even when it's costly this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you are avoiding a difficult decision to obey God
Think about how Paul's willingness to die for Christ (v.23) can inspire you to face a trial
Practically, how can you take one step of obedience today, like Paul's submission (v.24)

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray specifically about Paul's willingness to die for Jesus and the church's response to God's will.
tips: Thank God for the example of Paul who willingly submitted to the cross
Pray for the courage to face your own trials with faith
Ask God to help you say 'the will of the Lord be done' when you are tempted to give up

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 22:1-21 aloud, focusing on Paul's testimony in verses 3-12 and the crowd's reaction in verse 15.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Jew' in verse 3: 'a Jew, born in Tarsus'
Pay attention to the voice from heaven: 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?' (verse 8)
The crowd's cry: 'Gentiles' (verse 15) is a pivotal moment

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) does WHAT (testifies to his past and conversion) WHERE (in Jerusalem before the crowd) and WHY (to defend himself and explain his mission).
tips: Include Paul's background: born in Tarsus, educated in Jerusalem under Gamaliel
Note the key event: the Damascus road conversion where he saw Jesus
The crowd's reaction when he says 'Gentiles' (verse 15)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's confession of persecution (verse 4), the voice from heaven (verses 7-8), or the crowd's cry at 'Gentiles' (verse 15)?
tips: Paul's immediate confession: 'I am a Jew, born in Tarsus' (verse 3) shows his identity
The voice: 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?' (verse 8) is a profound personal encounter
The crowd's cry: 'Gentiles' (verse 15) is a dramatic shift in the mission

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage?
tips: Luke shows Paul as a transformed believer who now has a mission for the Gentiles
This passage illustrates the call of the gospel to reach beyond Jewish boundaries
The church's role in spreading the gospel to all people

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? Consider the conversion story, Roman citizenship, or the role of the high priest.
tips: The term 'persecuting the Way' (verse 4) refers to the early Christian movement, not just any group
The Roman citizenship: Paul was a Roman citizen (verse 16) so he had legal protection, but the tribune is afraid because he's a Roman
The 'high priest' (verse 5) refers to the Jewish religious leader, not the Roman authorities

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Paul was commissioned to be a witness to all people (verse 12). What situation requires you to trust God's call to be a witness this week?
tips: Consider an area where you feel called to share your faith
Think about how you can be a witness in your community
How can you be like Paul: obedient to God's call even when it's unpopular?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about Paul's commission to the Gentiles and his transformation.
tips: Thank God for the gift of the gospel to the Gentiles
Pray for courage to share your faith in a diverse world
Ask God to help you be a witness to others as Paul was

chapters.chapterTitle: Paul Before Festus and Appeal to Caesar

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 25:1-26 aloud, paying attention to the emotional tone of Paul's declaration of innocence (v. 24) and Festus' decision (v. 25).
tips: Notice the repeated phrase 'I am standing before Caesar's tribunal' (v. 24) shows Paul's confidence in the Roman legal system
Pay attention to Festus' shift from reluctance to agreement with Paul's appeal (v. 25)
The phrase 'appeal to Caesar' (v. 25) is the key phrase that echoes Christ's promise of being brought to Rome

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO is involved, WHAT is happening, WHERE it takes place, and WHY Paul is appealing to Caesar.
tips: Include Festus' initial reluctance to try Paul in Jerusalem and the Jews' false accusations
Note Paul's declaration: 'I am standing before Caesar's tribunal, where I ought to be tried'
Highlight the outcome: Festus allows Paul to appeal to Caesar

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's declaration of innocence (v. 24), Festus' decision (v. 25), or the invitation to Agrippa (v. 26)?
tips: Paul's statement: 'I am standing before Caesar's tribunal, where I ought to be tried' shows his confidence in the Roman legal system and Christ's authority
Festus' final decision: 'To Caesar you shall go' (v. 25) demonstrates the Roman legal process being used for God's purpose
The contrast between the Jews' false accusations and Paul's clear statement of innocence

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage?
tips: Luke emphasizes that Paul's appeal to Caesar is a divine plan: Christ promised Paul would testify in Rome (Acts 24:25) and God sovereignly uses Roman law to protect His witness
This passage shows that Paul's innocence and the legal process are part of God's sovereign plan to advance the gospel to the heart of the empire

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The Roman legal system, the role of Festus, or why Paul appeals to Caesar?
tips: Festus is a Roman official, but the Jewish leaders are trying to have Paul killed in Jerusalem  this shows the tension between Roman law and Jewish law
The phrase 'appeal to Caesar' (v. 25) might seem odd because Paul is already in Roman territory, but it was a formal legal process for serious crimes
The distinction between 'offense against the law of the Jews' (v. 24) and 'offense against Caesar' (the Roman emperor) is critical

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Paul's appeal to Caesar shows he was confident in the Roman legal system as a place of justice. What area of your life requires you to trust God's provision and authority this week?
tips: Consider a situation where you feel you are being judged or accused by others
Think about how you can stand confidently in God's authority, like Paul did

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God that He uses the Roman legal system to protect His people and trust in His sovereignty.
tips: Thank God that He uses the Roman legal system to protect His people
Pray for courage to stand in the face of false accusations and trust in God's justice
Ask God to strengthen your confidence in His provision and authority

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 26:1-23 aloud, focusing on the dialogue between Paul and Agrippa, especially the key phrases about the road to Damascus and the commission.
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Saul' in the voice of Jesus (v.16)
Pay attention to the phrase 'turn them from darkness to light' (v.18) which is a powerful metaphor
Note the contrast between Paul's past persecution and his current mission

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul) is defending, WHAT (his life and conversion), WHERE (before Agrippa in Jerusalem), and WHY (to be a witness to the Gentiles).
tips: Include Paul's past persecution of Christians (v.10-11)
Note that Paul was a Pharisee (v.6)
Highlight the commission to be a witness to Gentiles (v.18)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: the voice of Jesus (v.16), the commission (v.18), or Paul's statement about becoming 'such as I am' (v.20)?
tips: The voice of Jesus: 'Saul, Saul, why are you persecuting me?' is a personal and transformative moment
The commission to 'turn them from darkness to light' is a clear description of the mission of the church
Paul's statement: 'I would to God that all who hear me might become such as I amexcept for these chains' shows his desire for universal conversion

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage about Paul's trial?
tips: Luke emphasizes that Paul's conversion was by the power of the risen Christ, not human effort
The passage shows that the gospel is for the Gentiles, which was a radical extension of the promise to the fathers
This commission from Christ is the foundation of the early church's mission to the world

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The concept of 'the hope of the resurrection', the phrase 'the strictest party', or the mission to the Gentiles?
tips: 'The hope of the resurrection' refers to the resurrection of Christ as the promise that all who believe in Him will rise again
'The strictest party' refers to the Pharisees, who were the most rigorous in Jewish law
The mission to the Gentiles was a new direction for the church, as the early Christians were primarily Jewish

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: Paul was commissioned to be a witness to the Gentiles. What specific way can you share the hope of the resurrection with someone outside your cultural group this week?
tips: Think about a person who might not know about the resurrection
How can you be a 'witness' in your daily life, even with limited resources?
Remember that Paul's mission was not just for the Jews but for all people

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for the hope of the resurrection and ask for the courage to be a witness to the world.
tips: Thank God for Christ's resurrection and the promise of new life
Pray for the strength to share the gospel with non-Jews in your community
Ask God to help you become 'such as Paul'a witness to the world

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 27:1-31 aloud, paying attention to Paul's warning about the voyage and the angel's message.
tips: Notice Paul's warning: 'Men, I perceive this voyage will be with injury and much loss' (v.20)
Pay attention to the shift from a gentle south wind to a tempestuous northeaster (v.13)
The repeated phrase 'do not be afraid' (v.24) and the angel's promise

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: In your own words, describe WHO (Paul and the crew), WHAT (the voyage and shipwreck), WHERE (the sea and coast of Asia), and WHY (Paul's warning about the danger).
tips: Include the centurion Julius and the pilot who initially disagree with Paul
Note the jettisoning of cargo and ship's tackle (v.39)
The angelic message: 'Do not be afraid, Paul; you must stand before Caesar' (v.24)

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part stood out most? Consider: Paul's warning (v.20), the angel's message (v.24), or the outcome of all 276 being saved (v.39).
tips: Paul's warning shows his awareness of the danger and his faithfulness to God even in the midst of chaos
The angel's message provides hope and a promise that Paul will stand before Caesar (implying a future trial but also salvation)
The fact that all 276 were saved despite the shipwreck demonstrates God's preservation

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus/the church through this passage?
tips: Luke emphasizes God's sovereignty in the midst of chaos: the storm and shipwreck are under God's control
Paul's experience shows that even in the most dire circumstances, God's promises are trustworthy
This passage foreshadows Paul's trial before Caesar (as the angel states) and the church's future

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts are challenging? The term 'northeaster', the meaning of Paul's warning about the voyage, or the jettisoning of the ship's cargo?
tips: In ancient maritime terms, a 'northeaster' was a sudden, violent wind from the north, which could be deadly for ships
The 'fast' refers to the time when the sun is at its highest (for sailing) - the fast was over meaning they were too late for the safe sailing season
Jettisoning means to throw overboard to save the ship, which was a common practice to prevent sinking

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you trust God's promise of safety in your current trial, like Paul did when the shipwreck occurred?
tips: Think of a situation where you feel the storm is coming (like a job loss, health issue, or relationship problem)
Recall Paul's warning: 'Do not be afraid' (v.24) and the fact that all 276 were saved
Pray for the strength to trust God's promise even when the circumstances seem dire

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together: Thank God for preserving Paul and his companions through the shipwreck. Ask for courage to trust God's promise in your own trials.
tips: Thank God for preserving Paul and his companions through the shipwreck
Ask for courage to trust God's promise in your current trials
Pray that God will use your current challenges to bring you closer to Him

questions.title: Read Aloud
questions.instruction: Read Acts 28:1-31 aloud, focusing on the emotional tension of the viper incident (verses 5-6) and the healing events (verses 13-14).
tips: Notice the repetition of 'Paul' (the name of the apostle) in the context of being tested and healed
Pay attention to the phrase 'the people thought he was a murderer' (v.6) which shows the fear and misunderstanding
Notice the shift from fear to acceptance when Paul doesn't die (v.8-9)

questions.title: Summary
questions.instruction: Summarize in your own words: Who (Paul and the Maltese people), What (the events on Malta and in Rome), Where (Malta and Rome), When (after the viper incident and during the two-year stay), and Why (to spread the gospel and be tried by the Jews).
tips: Include the healing of Publius's father (v.13-14) as a key event
Note that the Maltese people initially feared Paul but then accepted his healing power
Highlight the two-year stay in Rome (v.21-31) as the main period of preaching

questions.title: Best Bit
questions.instruction: What part of this chapter stood out most? Consider: the viper incident (v.5-6), the healing of Publius's father (v.13-14), or Paul's two years of preaching in Rome (v.21-31).
tips: The viper incident shows God's protection and the power of Christ even in the most dangerous situations
Publius's father being healed demonstrates the practical impact of faith and the gospel on physical ailments
Paul's two years of preaching without hindrance shows the unstoppable nature of the gospel when Christ is at the center

questions.title: Main Point
questions.instruction: What was Luke trying to communicate to Theophilus and the church through this chapter about Paul's journey to Rome?
tips: Luke emphasizes that Paul's mission to the Gentiles was successful and that God's provision (healings, protection) was part of the journey
The chapter shows that the gospel reaches the ends of the earth (Rome) through the work of the Holy Spirit
The two-year stay in Rome demonstrates that the gospel can be proclaimed boldly even in the face of opposition

questions.title: Difficulties
questions.instruction: What parts of this chapter are challenging to understand? Consider cultural context, unfamiliar terms, or theological concepts.
tips: The Maltese people's belief that Paul was a god (v.9-10) might be confusing because it's a pagan interpretation of the divine
The 'twin gods' on the ship (v.15) is a local Maltese deity, showing the cultural context of the island
Why did Paul preach for two years without hindrance? This shows that the gospel was being accepted by the church in Rome and that God was working through Paul without interference

questions.title: Application
questions.instruction: How can you apply the theme of healing and bold proclamation from this chapter this week?
tips: Think about someone in your life who is sick or suffering; consider how you can be a source of hope and healing through Christ
Practice the boldness of Paul by sharing the gospel with someone who is open to it this week
Reflect on the healing of Publius's father: how can you pray for someone's physical or emotional healing?

questions.title: Prayer
questions.instruction: Pray together about the theme of God's healing and the bold proclamation of the gospel in this chapter.
tips: Thank God for the miraculous healings that happen through Christ
Ask for the courage to preach the gospel boldly, even when it's difficult
Pray for the church in Rome to be a place of healing and unity
